text:
When changing your email strategy from simply sending out content on an ad-hoc regular basis to -> automated sequences, how do you treat existing subscribers? Add them in halfway through a sequence? Keep sending them emails manually like you used to?

Ideally, I don't want to:
1. Send them content they may have already seen (in previous emails or on the blog)
2. Continue sending a manual email when all new subscribers get the automated sequence(s).

text:
When creating listicles that include your own product, has anyone found the prime position to include theirs?

Instinct suggests #1 but I've got a real mixed bag.

text:
<@UJJFDTN8G> Yes - that's the million dollar question. While I'm used to adding my product(s) at the top of the list, I prefer being downright honest with audience - as to why I did it.

For example, if you read this blog post - <https://textback.ai/sms-marketing-platforms/>, you'll see that I've mentioned "Well, if you think we’re being biased, you need to tap into <http://Textback.ai|Textback.ai>."

You can also mention that "of course we're being biased, that's because we've personally experienced how powerful our product actually is."

attachments.fallback: Textback: The 5 Best SMS Marketing Platforms You Should Know About in 2022
attachments.text: Looking for the best SMS marketing platform? Discover the five most powerful ones to engage your users in 2022.
attachments.title: The 5 Best SMS Marketing Platforms You Should Know About in 2022

text: Just asking you to create a content marketing plan is very vague - agreed there's a lot that could encapsulate. If they've never done content marketing before, I'd try to focus on the easy wins / lowest hanging fruit rather than preparing anything too broad... and if you're the one who's doing the work in this case as well as preparing the plan, I'd recommend putting together a roadmap for 30-60-90 days that's a realistic estimate of what you could execute on in that timeline. I don't have a specific template in mind, sorry, but that's what I would start with.

elements.text: Hello everyone! I'm in something of a bind and hoping this hive mind can help. I'm working on some internal processes that will help my team identify how long tasks take vs. the price we are charging. My team is coming in super low and over-producing. The amount of scope creep is crazy. Sooo…does anyone have any direction for how long basic tasks *should* take? Ie - if we offer a blog article to a client- it's 2 hours, or copy refresh on a website is 5 hours. I've put some items together based on my freelance life and how long tasks typically take, but I can't seem to find anything else to corroborate other than my past experience. While I don't plan on getting this granular with it-I want to come to the table with a “well the average time it should take is x- but we spent Y in March” make sense??

text: top spot is usually the safest bet and it definitely converts for b2b, i think your instinct is correct. in b2c content on my own affiliate sites i’ve found the first 2 slots and final slot to have good conversion rates (the middle area tends to get scrolled past).

text: :wave: Hey there! Has anyone here adapted their team from a *quarterly* content planning cadence to *monthly*? Looking for tips / pitfalls to avoid to ensure we're both staying flexible and keeping up with expected output. Thanks!

elements.text: Hey there! Has anyone here adapted their team from a
quarterly
content planning cadence to
monthly
? Looking for tips / pitfalls to avoid to ensure we're both staying flexible and keeping up with expected output. Thanks!

text:
Working as a very small content team with all my clients, working quarterly never works and is time-consuming (especially when things change in agile startups).

My monthly plan is often my Trello board. I.e. Here's everything I want to get published, refreshed, moved along, researched, etc.

For *me*, that's what I need. For *the team*, that's what they need. For *the CEO*, that's what they get :laughing:

text:
We usually take the top spot. But if we're guest posting on a site that also offers a product relevant to the listicle, we offer them the top spot and put ours at number 2.

We've found anywhere in the top 3 to be ideal so far.

elements.text: We usually take the top spot. But if we're guest posting on a site that also offers a product relevant to the listicle, we offer them the top spot and put ours at number 2.
We've found anywhere in the top 3 to be ideal so far.

text:
I'd say, depending on how many items are on the list, the first couple spots are prime. Unless you are going from least relevant to most relevant, then the bottom is best.

I think being honest with your position is best, though.

text:
In one of my previous roles I was able to partner with a marketing ops professional who helped set up a super focused data collection layer through our Salesforce.

My team and I were able to track minute details about where people click inside blog posts, anchor text, buttons, CTAs, etc, etc. And then all those clicks got funneled into a SF report we could pull that funneled into the lead scoring system our demand gen team set up.

One day the CFO asked what the ROI on our content team was, and within 10 minutes we had a report on his desk that showed how many millions of $ in pipeline we contributed to from the last calendar year.

Def start talking with some ops people and explore what options you have to take your data collection and reporting to new depths! If you want some specific recs or questions you can DM me, don't want to shill in the channel here.

text:
Definitely agree with <@U03BGN7NVT9> here, get in touch with a Marketing Ops person to set up GA/Salesforce dashboards for you.

Take a look at your KPI and see what metrics influence it and work backwards from there.
For example if your KPI was to increase website visits by X% then your metrics will be sessions. The image shows a part of what my current dashboard looks like

Happy to answer any further questions!
